Q: Is it incorrect/undefined behavior when libraries are linked using relative path? A:

You have two different problems, associated with two different pieces of software. ldd is showing you an issue associated with the dynamic linker (a.k.a. dynamic loader or program loader). Your compiler is showing you an issue associated with the static linker.

There are multiple solutions to each problem, but one that would solve them both would be @WhiteOwl's suggestion to install libB (and libA too) to one of the system's default library folders, before you attempt to do anything with it. Details are system dependent, but perhaps /usr/local/lib or /usr/local/lib64 would be appropriate.

However, if both libs are part of the same project then it's probably not convenient to install one before building the other. In this case, some of your alternatives are

  • add the appropriate -L and -l options for libB to the link command for C

     -L../dir1 -L../dir2 -lA -lB

    or

  • pass an appropriate -rpath-link option to the (static) linker, paying appropriate attention to its sensitivity to the order of command-line options. I would expect that the -rpath-link would need to appear before -lA on the command line to be effective for locating shared library dependencies of libA. I suspect, however, that -rpath-link will require either an absolute path or an ${ORIGIN}-relative path.

     -L../dir1 -Wl,-rpath-link="$(pwd)/../dir2" -lA

    Beware that -rpath-link may have unwanted side effects under some circumstances.

I repeat, however, that these alternatives solve only one of your two problems.

Q: How can I make a time-sensitive prompt in python? (Interrupting raw_input) A:

The way I have solved this problem is by using separate threads both to take user input and to check after a while if the user has entered a value. If a value is entered, a Boolean is set that prevents the execution of the wait method code, and the method that performs the calculation is executed, if not, it is executed with an arbitrary parameter, and it calls the one that continues with the program flow.

import threading 

did_not_enter_a_number = True
result = 0

  # this function is used to resume program flow after
  # **request_value** or **timeout** have been executed.
def I_do_something_with_the_result():
    print( f" - result -> {result}" )
    
def request_value():
    num = input( "Enter a integer" )

      # If the user enters a value, we set **did_not_enter_a_number** to
      # “False” so that the **timeout()** function does not execute its code.
    global did_not_enter_a_number
    did_not_enter_a_number = False
    multiply_by_2( num )
   
def multiply_by_2( num ):
    global result
    if num == 0:
        result = 0
    result = int( num ) * 2
    I_do_something_with_the_result()
    
  # we create a thread with the parameter
  # *demon = True*, so that it can be stopped.
t1 = threading.Thread( target = request_value );  
t1.daemon = True

def timeout():

      # if, at the end of the waiting time, no value has been 
      # entered, we call **multiply_by_2** with a “0,”
    if did_not_enter_a_number:

          # stop thread
        t1.finish = True
        print( " timeout!!!" )
        multiply_by_2( 0 )
        
  # we created the thread with a timer, we pass the wait
  # time and the function to be executed as parameters.
  # the thread will start after 5 seconds
temporizadorA = threading.Timer( 5, function = timeout )  
temporizadorA.start()  
t1.start()

Q: How to create a file in Ruby A:

There are several different options you could try. (This is not meant to be an exhaustive list... just tiring.)

File.new

file_name = File.new("out.txt", "w")
file_name.close

File.open

File.open("out.txt", "w") do |file|
  #other stuff here
end

File.write

File.write('out.txt', 'contents here')

FileUtils.touch

require 'fileutils'
FileUtils.touch('out.txt')

IO.sysopen and IO.sysnew

fd = IO.sysopen("out.txt", "w")
file = IO.new(fd, "w")
file.puts "other stuff"
file.close

Tempfile

require 'tempfile'
tempfile = Tempfile.new('out')
tempfile.puts "some text"
tempfile.close

Pathname and open

require 'pathname'
path = Pathname.new("out.txt")
path.open("w") do |file|
  file.puts "some text"
end

Q: HTML <img> tag does not show image from NAS drive A:

file:// may be one of the ways to fix the issue (but depending on whether your NAS allows the browser to access in this way. It may not work if access to the target files / folders require login credentials)

Alternatively, if you want to let the web browser able to access (and display) the P1020368.JPG in the NAS Bilder/Test directory, you may simply enable the web server in your NAS (most of today's NAS such as Qnap and Synology will allow you to do so)

For Qnap, you may refer to the following official documentation link:

https://docs.qnap.com/operating-system/qts/4.5.x/en-us/GUID-1C3A7404-D511-48A9-995B-6E75C880AD1D.html

For Synology

https://kb.synology.com/en-global/DSM/tutorial/How_to_host_a_website_on_Synology_NAS

After that, the mapped folder may be something like (depending on your configuration)

http://[your NAS IP or domain name]/Test/P1020368.JPG

Q: Show distinct column values in pyspark dataframe A:

I did some research on this to find which is performant

Below are my findings

create a 1 millon sample rows to test on databricks

from pyspark.sql import SparkSession
from pyspark.sql import functions as F
import time
import random
import string
import psutil
import os

# Initialize Spark session
spark = SparkSession.builder.appName("DistinctPerformanceTest").getOrCreate()

# Function to generate random usernames
def random_username(length=8):
    return ''.join(random.choices(string.ascii_lowercase, k=length))

# Create large synthetic dataset
num_rows = 1000000
data = [(i, random_username()) for i in range(num_rows)]
columns = ["id", "username"]
df = spark.createDataFrame(data, columns)

# Helper to get current process memory in MB
def get_memory_mb():
    process = psutil.Process(os.getpid())
    return process.memory_info().rss / (1024 * 1024)

print(f"Driver memory before execution: {get_memory_mb():.2f} MB")

# ------------------------------
# Method 1: collect_set()
start_cs = time.time()
unique_cs = df.select(F.collect_set("username").alias("unique_usernames")).first()["unique_usernames"]
end_cs = time.time()
mem_cs = get_memory_mb()
print(f"collect_set(): {len(unique_cs)} unique usernames, Time: {end_cs-start_cs:.2f}s, Driver Memory: {mem_cs:.2f} MB")

# ------------------------------
# Method 2: distinct().collect()
start_dc = time.time()
unique_dc_rows = df.select("username").distinct().collect()
unique_dc = [row[0] for row in unique_dc_rows]
end_dc = time.time()
mem_dc = get_memory_mb()
print(f"distinct().collect(): {len(unique_dc)} unique usernames, Time: {end_dc-start_dc:.2f}s, Driver Memory: {mem_dc:.2f} MB")

spark.stop()

Result : collect_set is clear winner among these 2 approaches

Q: How to install GitFlow for Windows A:

On Microsoft Windows 10/11, you can try the following:

Download and install the tools using WinGet:

`winget install --id Git.Git --source winget`

`winget install --id GitTower.GitFlowNext --source winget`

Find the installation path using PowerShell:

`Get-Command git-flow* | Format-List Name,Source`

You may see something like this:

Name   : git-flow-v0.1.1-windows-amd64.exe
Source : C:\Users\my-user\AppData\Local\Microsoft\WinGet\Packages\GitTower.GitFlowNext_Microsoft.Winget.Source_8wekyb3d8bbwe\git-flow-v0.1.1-windows-amd64.exe

Copy the value of 'Source' and finally, create an alias for Git Flow in the global Git for Windows configuration:

`git config --global alias.flow '!f(){ "{GIT_FLOW_NEXT_INSTALLATION_PATH}" "$@"; };` f'

* Replace {GIT_FLOW_NEXT_INSTALLATION_PATH} with the full path that appears in "Source" when searching in PowerShell for the Git Flow Next command in yours results.

Test if it works with:

git flow version

If you see something like:

git-flow-next version 0.1.1

Everything is working correctly.
